title: Paul's Defense Before Felix
shortSummary: Acts 24 records the formal trial of the Apostle Paul before the Roman governor Felix, where Paul defends himself against accusations brought by Jewish leaders. The chapter highlights Paul's unwavering faith, his hope in the resurrection, and Felix's indecision, which results in Paul’s prolonged imprisonment.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Imprisonment in Caesarea

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The Apostle on trial, defending his faith and conduct before Governor Felix.

keyCharacters.name: Felix
keyCharacters.description: Roman governor of Judea who hears Paul's defense and delays judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Ananias
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who, along with elders and Tertullus, accuses Paul.

keyCharacters.name: Tertullus
keyCharacters.description: An orator who presents the formal accusations against Paul to Felix.

keyCharacters.name: Drusilla
keyCharacters.description: Felix’s Jewish wife who is present when Paul speaks about faith in Christ.

definitions.definition: A belief or practice that deviates from orthodox Christian doctrine; here referring to the early Christian faith as viewed by Jewish opponents.
The Christian hope that all people will be raised to life after death, both the just and unjust.
Charitable giving to the poor, an important Jewish religious duty.
God’s sovereign care and governance over the world, referenced by Tertullus in praise of Felix’s rule.
A Roman officer in charge of about one hundred soldiers, here assigned to guard Paul.

outline.heading: The Accusation Against Paul
outline.description: Ananias, elders, and Tertullus formally accuse Paul of being a troublemaker, a sectarian leader, and a temple profaner, appealing to Felix’s authority to judge him.

outline.heading: Paul’s Defense
outline.description: Paul respectfully defends himself, denying the charges, affirming his adherence to the Jewish faith, and emphasizing his belief in the resurrection, which is the real cause of his persecution.

outline.heading: Felix’s Response and Paul’s Imprisonment
outline.description: Felix, familiar with ‘the Way,’ postpones a decision, grants Paul some freedom, and listens to Paul’s teaching about righteousness and judgment, yet delays justice, hoping for a bribe, resulting in Paul’s continued imprisonment.

application: Stand firm in your faith and be ready to give a reason for your hope, even when falsely accused or misunderstood.
Maintain a clear conscience before God and man by living a life consistent with biblical truth.
Trust God’s timing and sovereignty, even when justice seems delayed or circumstances are difficult.
Engage respectfully and lovingly with those who oppose the gospel, seeking to witness through your conduct and words.

keyVerses.text: And have hope toward God, which they themselves also allow, that there shall be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and unjust.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates the core of Christian hope and the cause of Paul’s persecution.

keyVerses.text: And herein do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void of offence toward God, and toward men.
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s commitment to a blameless conscience is a model for Christian integrity.

keyVerses.text: And as he reasoned of righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come, Felix trembled, and answered, Go thy way for this time; when I have a convenient season, I will call for thee.
keyVerses.significance: Felix’s reaction shows the power of the gospel to convict, even in a political setting.
